response.answer_text: Oral ulceration is one of the commonest diseases of the mucosa, but this should not make the patient take it lightly. Sometimes oral ulceration can be a very serious condition.  There are many reasons for oral ulcerations: 1. Trauma: and this could be due to mechanical forces (such as trauma caused when you accidentally bite your cheeks, or when you scratch your mucosa with some hard foods), thermal (when you eat or drink something very hot), and chemical (for instance when chewing aspirin, or when accidentally dangerous acids are drunk mistakenly as water). 2. Diseases: the list is huge; some of the diseases are of bacterial, viral or fungal cause, while others are simply idiopathic. The most common ones are:  (Pediatric Aphthous Ulcers - Medscape) Recurrent aphthous stomatitis (RAS): very common, affects 5-66% of the population. The etiology of RAS is not entirely clear. There seems to be some genetic basis for RAS. It can also be a manifestation of a group of disorders. Herpes simplex virus: the most common cause is HSV-1, however HSV-2 could also have oral manifestations.Herpes zoster.Herpangina (very common in children).HIV infection.3. Autoimmune conditions such as Behçet syndrome, Lichen planus and others. 4. Irradiation and chemotherapy. 5. Neoplastic conditions: squamous cell carcinoma (SSC), is by far the most common (accounts for about 90% of all oral cancers). 6. Medications and drugs: in addition to the previously mentioned chemotherapeutic agents, non steroid anti inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) are very common cause. Cocaine causes oral ulcers when in contact with the mucosa. There are many other causes, but I believe these are the ones we see on daily basis.

In many cases, the reason for mouth ulcers is unclear. Most single mouth ulcers are caused by damage to the lining inside of the mouth. For example: accidentally biting the inside of your cheek or a sharp toothpoorly fitting dentureshard fooda defective fillingIt’s not always clear what causes mouth ulcers that keep returning, but triggers are thought to include: stress and anxietyhormonal changes – some women develop mouth ulcers during their monthly periodeating certain foods – such as chocolate, spicy foods, coffee, peanuts, almonds, strawberries, cheese, tomatoes and wheat flourtoothpaste containing sodium lauryl sulphatestopping smoking – when you first stop smoking, you may develop mouth ulcersMedical conditions :- Mouth ulcers can sometimes be caused by certain medical conditions, such as: viral infections – including the cold sore virus ,chickenpox, and hand, foot and mouth diseasevitamin B12 or iron deficiencyCrohn's disease – a long-term condition that causes inflammation of the lining of the digestive systemcoeliac disease – a common digestive condition where a person has an adverse reaction to glutenreactive arthritis – a condition that causes inflammation in various places in the body, usually as a reaction to an infectionweakened immune system – for example, due to HIV orlupusBehcet’s disease – a rare and poorly understood condition that also causes swelling of the blood vessels.
